answer_html: Since -8 is not -12, we can conclude that the point P is not on this curve.
answer_latex:
Since -8 is not -12, we can conclude that the point \emph{P} is not on
this curve.
hints_html: A point (a, b) is on the curve y = \(f(x)\) if and only if \(f(a)\) = b.
hints_latex:
A point (\emph{a}, \emph{b}) is on the curve \emph{y} = $f(x)$ if
and only if $f(a)$ = \emph{b}.
hints_raw: A point (''a'', ''b'') is on the curve ''y'' = &fnof;(''x'') if and only if &fnof;(''a'') = ''b''.
question: 7 (a)
sols_html:
As mentioned in the hint, a point is on a curve if its coordinates satisfy the curve equation. So we simply compute:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(4) = 4^2 - 6\cdot 4 = 16 - 24 = -8\end{aligned}\]

Since -8 is not -12, we can conclude that the point P is not on this curve.
sols_latex:
As mentioned in the hint, a point is on a curve if its coordinates
satisfy the curve equation. So we simply compute:

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f(4) = 4^2 - 6\cdot 4 = 16 - 24 = -8
\end{align*}

Since -8 is not -12, we can conclude that the point \emph{P} is not on
this curve.
sols_raw:
As mentioned in the hint, a point is on a curve if its coordinates satisfy the curve equation. So we simply compute:
:<math>\displaystyle
f(4) = 4^2 - 6\cdot 4 = 16 - 24 = -8
</math>

Since -8 is not -12, we can conclude that the point ''P'' is not on this curve.
statement_html:
Let \(f(x)\) = x2 - 6x and let P be the point (4, -12).

a) Is P on the curve y = \(f(x)\)? Justify your answer.
statement_latex:
Let $f(x)$ = \emph{x}\textsuperscript{2} - 6\emph{x} and let
\emph{P} be the point (4, -12).

a) Is \emph{P} on the curve \emph{y} = $f(x)$? Justify your answer.
statement_raw:
Let &fnof;(''x'') = ''x''<sup>2</sup> - 6''x'' and let ''P'' be the point (4, -12).  

a) Is ''P'' on the curve ''y'' = &fnof;(''x'')? Justify your answer.
